description: Nikola Petrak decides to quietly support the emerging free councils. He delivers archive access codes and original documents to trusted neighborhood leaders, encouraging them to organize open truth assemblies despite risks of confusion and division.
Neighborhood review teams receive access to confidential archives and begin vetting evidence of BCI abuses. Communal forums are organized, inviting residents to testify and compare records.

City squares across free zones host Truth and Repairs Assemblies. Citizens come forward to share personal accounts of harm caused by the BCI. The process is chaotic but empowering, as communities debate and interpret the records together.

Council loyalists attempt to discredit the assemblies, spreading misinformation and submitting fake testimonies, creating confusion. Protesters and local review teams push back, demanding stricter validation and exposing deception.

Despite disruption, grassroots verification efforts adapt and persist. New citywide trust networks emerge—some deeply skeptical, others supportive—fundamentally altering relationships between citizens, councils, and power.
